description: Game show contestants using questionable logic to win prizes

scenarios.title: Pie Throwing Champion
scenarios.content: On a wacky game show, a contestant claims to be the world's greatest pie thrower because he can hit a bullseye from 10 feet away. He says this makes him the obvious choice to win the grand prize.
scenarios.audioScript:
Host: [excited] "Welcome back to our Pie Throwing Championship! Let's meet our next contestant, Billy."

Billy: [smug] "I'm the world's greatest pie thrower. Just last week, I hit a bullseye from 10 feet away. Obviously that means I'm going to win the grand prize today!"

Host: [impressed] "Wow, 10 feet is pretty far! Sounds like you've got this in the bag."

Contestant2: [skeptical] "Hold on, just because you hit one bullseye doesn't mean you're the best. Shouldn't we see how everyone else does first?"

Billy: [dismissive] "Nah, my one amazing shot proves I'm the champ. Let's just give me the prize now!"
scenarios.claim: Billy is the world's greatest pie thrower and sure to win the contest because he hit a bullseye from 10 feet away one time.

logicalFallacies.example: Concluding he is the world's best pie thrower from a single bullseye.

scenarios.title: Winning the Wacky Prize
scenarios.content: On the zany game show Wacky Prizes, contestants compete in silly challenges to win strange prizes. When deciding who should win the coveted Pickle Polisher 3000, questionable reasoning leads to a heated debate.
scenarios.audioScript:
Host: [enthusiastic] "Welcome back to Wacky Prizes! It's time to award the Pickle Polisher 3000! Let's ask our contestants why they think they deserve it."

Contestant 1: [confident] "I should win because I'm the oldest and wisest contestant here. Age equals wisdom!"

Contestant 2: [dismissive] "That's ridiculous. Everybody knows redheads are the luckiest. And since I'm the only redhead, I'll have the best luck with the prize!"  

Contestant 3: [worried] "I'm scared that if I don't win, I'll be the laughingstock of my neighborhood. My life will be ruined! I need this!"

Host: [amused] "Wow, these are some interesting arguments! Who will the audience pick?"
scenarios.claim: The contestant with the most compelling reason deserves to win the Pickle Polisher 3000.

logicalFallacies.example: Contestant 1 argues they should win because they are the oldest, implying age gives authority.
Contestant 2 makes a broad generalization that all redheads are lucky.
Contestant 3 argues they should win by claiming their life will be ruined otherwise, appealing to fear.

scenarios.title: Longest Mustache Wins!
scenarios.content: On a wacky game show, the host declares the contestant with the longest mustache will win the grand prize. Chaos ensues as contestants argue over mustache superiority.
scenarios.audioScript:
Host: [excited] "Welcome back to Crazy Quiz! It's time for our lightning round. The contestant with the longest mustache wins our grand prize!" 

Contestant 1: [smug] "My mustache is clearly the longest. I've been growing it for 10 years!"

Contestant 2: [defensive] "Length isn't everything! My mustache is thick and luxurious. That's what counts."  

Contestant 3: [indignant] "Fake news! Everyone knows handlebar mustaches are the only REAL mustaches. If yours doesn't curl up at the ends, you're disqualified!"

Host: [amused] "Looks like we have a hairy situation! While you sort this out, a word from our sponsor: Marvelous Mustache Wax!"
scenarios.claim: The contestant with the longest mustache should win the game show prize.

logicalFallacies.example: The contestants argue about mustache thickness and style, which are irrelevant to the original claim about length.
Contestant 3 suggests handlebar mustaches are the only 'real' mustaches, falsely equating style with authenticity.

scenarios.title: Wacky Word Wizards
scenarios.content: On the game show Wacky Word Wizards, contestants compete to define silly words. When Bill disagrees with Jill's definition, she claims his opinion doesn't matter because he has a silly mustache. The host awards Jill the points.
scenarios.audioScript:
Host: [excited] Welcome back to Wacky Word Wizards, the show where contestants compete to create the wackiest definitions for made-up words! Our next word is... 'Snorkelwhiffer'! Jill, let's hear your definition.

Jill: [confident] A Snorkelwhiffer is a special nose plug that helps you smell underwater.  

Bill: [skeptical] That doesn't make any sense. You can't smell underwater, plug or no plug!

Jill: [dismissive] Well, what do you know, Bill? With that ridiculous mustache, you look like a Snorkelwhiffer yourself! 

Host: [amused] Oooh, burn! That's a low blow, Jill, but I like it! You win the points for that round!

Bill: [exasperated] What? That's not fair! My mustache has nothing to do with this.

Host: [grinning] Sure it does, Bill. The points go to the best zinger!
scenarios.claim: Jill's argument is valid because Bill has a silly mustache.

logicalFallacies.example: Jill attacks Bill's appearance instead of addressing his argument.

scenarios.title: Slimy Slime Quiz Scandal
scenarios.content: On the hit game show Slimy Slime Quiz, a contestant makes a wild claim to try to win the grand prize - a lifetime supply of slime. Will their faulty logic prevail or will the host see through their flawed argument?
scenarios.audioScript:
Host: [excited] "Welcome back to Slimy Slime Quiz, the show where you can win a lifetime supply of slime! Our next contestant is Becky. Becky, are you ready to play?"

Becky: [confident] "I was born ready! And I have a foolproof way to win."

Host: [intrigued] "Oh really? Do tell."

Becky: [smug] "Well, slime is made from natural ingredients like glue and borax. Anything natural must be good for you. Therefore, if I eat nothing but this slime, I'll be the healthiest kid ever! You have to give me the lifetime supply so I can be super healthy."

Host: [skeptical] "Hmmm I'm not so sure about that logic. Natural doesn't always mean healthy."

Becky: [insistent] "But slime is natural and I want it, so it must be good! Why won't you give it to me? You must want kids to be unhealthy!"

Host: [flustered] "No, that's not it at all! I just think maybe a lifetime supply of slime isn't the healthiest prize..."
scenarios.claim: If I eat nothing but natural slime, I'll be the healthiest kid ever, so I should win a lifetime supply of slime.

logicalFallacies.example: Assuming that slime is healthy to eat just because it contains some natural ingredients.
Implying the host either has to give her the slime or he wants kids to be unhealthy.

scenarios.title: Wheel of Fishy Wisdom
scenarios.content: On a wacky game show, contestants compete to win prizes by making outrageous arguments. They spin a 'Wheel of Wisdom' to get debate topics, then try to convince the host using silly logic. Who will win the grand prize with the most persuasive nonsense?
scenarios.audioScript:
Host: [cheerful] Welcome back to Wheel of Fishy Wisdom, the game show where saying the silliest things can win you fabulous prizes! Let's meet our contestants. 

Contestant 1: [excited] I'm Wally and I'm here to win that dream vacation to Wackyworld!

Contestant 2: [competitive] I'm Wendy and I'll do whatever it takes to get that shiny new hoverboard!

Host: Alright, let's get this party started! Wally, you're up first. Give that wheel a big spin!

[wheel spinning sound effect]

Host: Your topic is...pets. Make your case! 

Wally: [smug] Well, everyone knows that goldfish make the best pets. I mean, all the cool kids have goldfish. If you don't have a goldfish, you're basically a nobody. Goldfish are the only pet that matters.

Host: Ooh, compelling argument Wally! Wendy, your rebuttal?

Wendy: [dismissive] Pfft, goldfish are so last year. If you want to be cool, you need a pet rock. They've been around forever, so you know they're legit. It's just natural to have a pet rock.

Host: What a matchup, folks! Who will the jury find more convincing - Wally with his popular goldfish or Wendy's tried and true pet rock? While they deliberate, we'll be right back!
scenarios.claim: The best pet is whichever one is most popular or traditional.

logicalFallacies.example: Wally argues goldfish are the best pets because all the cool kids have them.
Wendy claims pet rocks are best because they've been around forever.

scenarios.title: Crazy Quiz Craze
scenarios.content: On a zany game show, contestant Gus claims he should win because he's been on the most game shows. His bizarre logic baffles the host and other players.
scenarios.audioScript:
Host: [excited] Welcome back to Crazy Quiz Craze! Let's check in with our contestants before the next round. Gus, tell us a bit about yourself.

Gus: [smug] Well, I've been a contestant on 27 different game shows, so I think it's obvious I should win this one too. I have the most experience!

Host: [confused] Err, I'm not sure that's how it works, Gus. Anyone can win, regardless of past game show appearances.

Betty: [annoyed] Yeah, that's a silly reason to think you're going to win. Shouldn't it come down to who plays the best today?

Gus: [defensive] Hey, I paid my dues. When you've done as many shows as I have, then you can talk! 

Doug: [amused] Dude, you could go on 100 shows, doesn't mean you'll magically win this one. What counts is getting the answers right, not your resume!

Host: [laughing] Okay, let's get back to the game, shall we? Remember, everyone has an equal shot at our grand prize, no matter how many times you've played before!
scenarios.claim: I should win this game show because I've been a contestant on the most game shows in the past.

logicalFallacies.example: Gus thinks he should win because of his past experience on many game shows, even though that's irrelevant to his performance in this specific game.

scenarios.title: The Price is Seriously Wrong
scenarios.content: On the popular game show 'The Price is Seriously Wrong', contestant Sammy makes some questionable arguments to try to win a fabulous prize. Can you spot the flaws in Sammy's logic?
scenarios.audioScript:
Host: [enthusiastic] "Welcome back to The Price is Seriously Wrong! Sammy, for a chance to win this shiny new bicycle, tell us why the price should be $1 million."

Sammy: [confident] "Well everyone knows bicycles are the transportation of the future since they don't pollute. So a futuristic bike like this one that can save the planet should cost at least $1 million!"

Host: [intrigued] "Interesting point Sammy! What else?"

Sammy: [insistent] "Plus, my sister said her friend bought a bike for a million dollars, so that must be the going rate these days."

Host: [impressed] "Hard to argue with that logic, Sammy! Judges, what do you think, is Sammy our big winner today?"

Judge: [contemplative] "Hmm, those are some compelling arguments...but something doesn't quite add up. What do you think at home - does Sammy's reasoning make sense or is the price seriously wrong?"
scenarios.claim: A bicycle should cost $1 million because bikes are good for the environment and my sister's friend bought one for that price.

logicalFallacies.example: Bicycles are good for the environment, so an eco-friendly bike should cost $1 million.
My sister's friend bought a $1 million bike, so that must be the normal price everyone pays.

scenarios.title: Slime Time Shenanigans
scenarios.content: On a wacky kids game show, two contestants argue over who should win the final slime bucket challenge and take home the grand prize.
scenarios.audioScript:
Announcer: [excited] "Welcome back to Slime Time! It's time for our final challenge to see which lucky contestant will win the vacation of their dreams!"

Kid 1: [confident] "I've been on this show way longer than my opponent. I've paid my dues and deserve to win!"

Kid 2: [annoyed] "That's not how it works! The winner should be whoever does the best in the last challenge. Time on the show doesn't matter."

Kid 1: [smug] "Well, the producers told me they were rooting for me to win since I'm such a fan favorite. So it's pretty much guaranteed."  

Kid 2: [shocked] "What? That can't be true! The winner is supposed to be decided fair and square. You're just making that up!"

Kid 1: [dismissive] "Believe what you want, but I'm walking out of here covered in victory slime and headed to Hawaii! It's destiny!"
scenarios.claim: I should win the game show prize because I've been on the show longer and the producers want me to win.

logicalFallacies.example: Claiming the producers want them to win as if that decides who should win, regardless of the challenge.
Equating time spent on the show with deserving to win, even though the rules state the final challenge determines the winner.

scenarios.title: Slime Time Mayhem
scenarios.content: On a wacky game show called Slime Time, contestants make wild claims to try to win the grand prize - a lifetime supply of slime. But some of their arguments are pretty slimy too!
scenarios.audioScript:
Announcer: [excited] "Welcome back to Slime Time, the show where contestants compete to win a lifetime supply of slime! Let's check in with our contestants..."

Contestant1: [confident] "I deserve to win because I'm the oldest kid here. Everyone knows older kids are smarter and better at games."

Contestant2: [dismissive] "No way, you're wrong! My dad says I'm the best at everything, so I should win. Are you saying my dad is a liar?"

Contestant3: [worried] "I heard that if you don't win slime, you turn into slime! I don't want that to happen to me!"

Contestant1: [smug] "See? Contestant3 is just a scaredy-cat. Looks like it's down to you and me. But you're wearing a purple shirt, and purple is an unlucky color. So I win!"

Announcer: [amused] "Wow, these are some creative arguments! Who will the judges pick? Find out after the break!"
scenarios.claim: I should win the slime because I'm the oldest.

logicalFallacies.example: Contestant1 argues they should win because they're the oldest, implying older kids are always smarter.
Contestant2 says they should win because their dad says they're the best at everything.
Contestant3 is worried that not winning slime will turn them into slime.
